shared_text:
Buncombe County Schools Nutrition is at Weaverville Elementary School.
April 9 at 3:11 PM ¬∑ Weaverville, NC ¬∑

The school nutrition super heroes at Weaverville Elementary School are full steam ahead this week, wearing upgraded gear to increase safety in Buncombe County.

A big shout out to the School Nutrition staff at Weaverville for modeling social distancing and sanitation standards! Across All Buncombe County Schools, serving safe and nutritious meals is our top priority. All School Nutrition staff are practicing official recommendations for social distancing and sanitation. Even under such rigorous conditions these heroes take pride in preparing high quality nutritious meals.

The Weaverville ES cafeteria staff is wearing masks made by Media Assistant Ms. Kelly Banner. Other masks throughout our cafeterias were also handmade! BCS school Nutrition is thankful to have such amazing support.

#schoollunch #schoolnutrition #schoolnutritionheroes #schoolnutritionprofessionals #schoolmealsthatrock #WeAreBCS #BCSrocks
#BCS #BCSadvantage #BCSstrong #BuncombeFeedsKids Buncombe County Schools

post_text:
#BCSstrong: The #BCS Family Resource Center benefited from a recent food drive courtesy of Brookstone Church in Weaverville. The church sorted and boxed over 300 meals to be distributed across four counties in the mountains. The Family Resource Center received a portion of those donations! We are now making deliveries to over 200 families who have limited ability to travel or are suffering a financial hardship during this unprecedented pandemic crisis. As our ability to serve expands, we so appreciate community partners like Brookstone Church who are able to provide much needed assistance. Thank you!

WLOS ABC 13
#BCready #buncombeready #wearebcs #bcsadvantage #ashevillestrong #asheville #avl #avlstrong #response #the828 #828isgreat

The Asheville Citizen Times and Ingles Markets honor graduating athletes in Buncombe County Schools and across Western North Carolina with a Virtual Senior Night!

‚ÄúMy favorite memory from high school sports was having an opportunity each and every day to be a part of a program that was much bigger than myself and was focused upon supporting and loving one another,‚Äù wrote A.C. Reynolds High School senior athlete Emma Jones in her profile.

Congratulations to our senior athletes for their many accomplishments!

Excerpt:
‚ÄúTo honor the accomplishments of athletes across WNC, the Citizen Times presents a virtual senior night to share with parents, players and coaches who are missing out on these special nights. Please take a moment to scroll through this list and help us honor our many seniors!‚Äù

post_text:
Thriving fine arts programs are grown through collaboration and leadership. When 25 art education leaders from across the country were chosen by the National Art Education Association to attend their School for Art Leaders last year, one familiar face joined them from Buncombe County Schools. Arts education specialist Ms. Laura Mitchell took full advantage of the opportunity to collaborate with successful art leaders and find ways to bring that knowledge to local public schools.

‚ÄúThe goal is to strengthen the community we have in the arts and to share resources, so we can diversify and broaden the arts opportunities available to our students,‚Äù Mitchell said.

BCS Arts #WeAreBCS #BCS #BCSadvantage #BCSarts #BCSvisualarts #BCSstrong #NAEA #FineArts #AVLart #AVLarts #828isreat #Asheville #Buncombe #BuncombeCounty #NCpublicschools #WNC #NorthCarolina #AVL

post_text:
#WeAreBCS: Even though she would rather put ukuleles or mountain dulcimers into her students‚Äô hands, Ms. Jennifer J. Anderson said Virtual Days online classes have created new opportunities for students to interact with music.

‚ÄúTheir reactions make it so interesting,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe younger kids will try anything. I even had them identifying major and minor chords, because they don‚Äôt know that‚Äôs hard. There‚Äôs excitement and spontaneity.‚Äù

Ms. Anderson, a music teacher at Pisgah Elementary School and W.D. Williams Elementary, said her online classroom has created a space where children discuss music during and even outside of their normal class time.

‚ÄúA lot of the kids that are really fired up about music are on there every day,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going outside and recording the sounds of nature. They‚Äôre making music journals and listening to new songs to draw inspiration. We‚Äôve got this whole community sharing ideas instead of feeling isolated.‚Äù

#BCS #BCSstrong #BCSadvantage #WNC #NorthCarolina #Buncombe #AVL #Asheville #BuncombeCounty #Education #PublicSchoolProud

Sports competitions may be temporarily on hold, but dreams are not! We love seeing our students get ready for college and the next level. üèÄ Congrats to Rocket senior Tyler Parton for being highlighted by our local news!

As reported by the Asheville Citizen Times:
"Reynolds senior Tyler Parton has committed to play college basketball.

Parton, who averaged 14.2 points, four rebounds and three assists a game for the Rockets during the 2019-20 season, announced his commitment to William Peace University on April 5."

Community kindness continues to pour out while we weather the storm together!

On Monday, Buncombe County Library staff delivered more than 500 new and used books and 250 activity kits to our Family Resource Center. These books and craft activities will give families more hands-on learning opportunities and new materials to read together. The donations came from the library and from Friends of Buncombe County Libraries, Inc.

üç≤ Spring Break Meals:
Meal service will continue uninterrupted throughout the BCS spring break (4/6 - 4/10) at all meal sites. Monday through Friday, breakfasts will be served from 7:30 a.m. - 8:30 a.m. and lunches will be served from 11:30 a.m. - 1:30 p.m.

During lunch on Friday, weekend meal boxes will also be sent home for students ages 2-18 . These boxes include lunches for Saturday and Sunday, and breakfasts for Saturday, Sunday, and Monday.

‚ÑπÔ∏è Visit Response.BuncombeSchools.org for up-to-date information, as well as meal sites and times.

post_text:
We're honored to help meet this need and keep our front line workers safe!

üóûÔ∏è In case you missed it, here's our recent story on this innovative new effort to manufacture face shield with our 3-D printers: https://www.facebook.com/BuncombeSchools/posts/3115182098493997

üé• As reported by WLOS ABC 13:
Buncombe County Schools is making face shields, using 3-D printing technology, to help keep those on the front lines safe.

The shields, designed to come over the N95 mask, are made of two types of plastic. There is a flexible headband, a strap to help adjust the mask and a transparency shield. There is also foam material to help keep molecules out of the mask.

post_text:
#BCSstrong: The Lowe's Home Improvement in Weaverville recently made a large donation to help #BCS serve children in our community. Lowe's donated hand trucks, large tote bags, and 50 buckets filled with cleaning and laundry supplies. Some items will be used at our meal sites and others will be donated through our Family Resource Center, which delivers supplies right to our students' doorsteps!

Lowe's store Manager James Edenfield said this donation idea was employee driven- the staff wanted to help families impacted by the coronavirus pandemic.

"It's phenomenal. It's great. The community is so supportive of the store, and this is a great environment. We are so happy to be able to give back to our community," said Mr. Edenfield.

Visit response.buncombeschools.org to find out more about how Buncombe County Schools is teaming up with various community partners to offer support at a time when our families need it most!

#BCReady #BuncombeReady #covid19 #coronavirus #avlstrong #ashevillestrong #wearebcs #bcsadvantage #avl #asheville #weaverville #wnc #828isgreat #the828

#BCSstrong: Three classrooms at Martin L. Nesbitt, Jr. Discovery Academy have been converted into manufacturing bays as Buncombe County Schools uses 3D printers to make critically important face shields for medical workers.

‚ÄúWhat this shows is that there are real-life applications to what we learn in school,‚Äù said Glen Arden Elementary School Media Specialist Lee Ann Smith. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not only for teaching and education purposes, but it can save people‚Äôs lives.‚Äù

"We are waking up as a community and realizing we‚Äôre stronger together," said #BCS Assistant Superintendent Joseph Hough. "And when the children see us stepping up, they‚Äôll see a model for how they can step up when they see a need.‚Äù

post_text:
#WeAreBCS: It‚Äôs World Autism Awareness Day, and our #BCS families are wearing blue to promote understanding and a more inclusive society!

BCS Autism Specialists Marlou de Vera and Aimee Adams work alongside teachers, sharing best methods and practices for behavioral, academic, and social success. During Virtual Days, they‚Äôre providing individualized virtual instruction and creating professional development materials for teachers and assistants.

‚ÄúWe help students integrate in their school and community,‚Äù Ms. de Vera said. ‚ÄúWe work with teachers to provide structure and encouragement to prepare all of our students for their tomorrow.‚Äù

Even though so many of us are at home, we want to share our love for every student, accommodate their needs, and celebrate their strengths. We are together even when we are apart.

#differentnotless #BCSstrong #BCSadvantage #Asheville #AVL #WNC #NCpublicschools #PublicSchoolProud #NorthCarolina #COVID19 #Coronavirus

During Virtual Days, they‚Äôre providing individualized virtual instruction and creating professional development materials for teachers and assistants.

Even though so many of us are at home, we want to share our love for every student, accommodate their needs, and celebrate their strengths. We are together even when we are apart.
